awd_titl_txt: Allosterically Regulated Supramolecular Capsules and Receptors Assembled via the WLA
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program, Professor Chad A. Mirkin of Northwestern University is developing design rules for the synthesis of special molecules that can serve as capsules with controllable size and recognition properties for applications in detectors, molecular separations, and catalysis. The rational design and synthesis of these capsules, is a significant challenge in the field of the assembly of supramolecular structures, could lead to significant advances related to the purification of pharmaceuticals essential in clinical medicine, the conversion of low-value to high-value chemical feedstocks important to the chemical and petroleum industries, and the development of chemical sensors critical to the environmental testing and food packaging fields. 

Specifically, this project focuses on the development of stimuli-responsive heterodimeric capsules, using robust and generalizable chemistry that can be implemented in a wide variety of settings. Various capsules are being synthesized and studied in the context of the Weak-Link approach, and the most promising are being characterized further using X-ray crystallography, multinuclear NMR spectroscopy, isothermal titration calorimetry, mass spectrometry, and UV-vis spectroscopy. The chemical and physical properties of these novel heterodimeric capsules are being defined through collaborative efforts with core facilities, such as the Integrated Molecular Structure Education and Research Center (IMSERC), at Northwestern University. Outreach programs aimed at engaging local high school students and undergraduates from around the world have been established by Mirkin. These programs focus on mentoring students, teaching them technical aspects of laboratory research, and preparing them for the next stage of their academic careers. These young students are learning about scientific research at the forefront of the field and interacting with leading scientists, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers. This work provides a training ground for young students, including underrepresented minorities, and equips them with basic science knowledge essential for developing technologies that can significantly improve the lives of many Americans.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Summary

Work in the context of this grant focused on understanding the dynamic nature of bio-inspired metallo-supramolecular complexes under various experimental conditions (e.g., environmental, solvent); furthermore, the groundwork necessary for interfacing these stimuli-responsive constructs with biomacromolecules and functional materials was laid. Of the various approaches to achieving such dynamic, molecular architectures, the Weak-Link Approach (WLA) to supramolecular chemistry was demonstrated as a powerful strategy for synthesizing metal-based complexes that could be reversibly toggled between multiple structural states. Specifically, with the WLA, macrocyclic, triple-decker, and tweezer-based constructs can be synthesized using multitopic, bidentate hemilabile ligands. In structures prepared based on the WLA, weakly binding hemilabile ligands at the metal nodes are displaced by more tightly binding small molecules or ions. As such, the metallo-supramolecular structure can be regulated between a "closed" rigid state and an "open" flexible state. Over the lifetime of this grant, significant progress has been made in designing and synthesizing new modular WLA architectures and understanding their complex functionalities. For instance, we: 1) synthesized a multi-state WLA macrocycle and developed a four-state molecular switching system; 2) established a strategy for controlling the "open" and "closed" state of an allosteric WLA complex using redox chemistry; 3) discovered dynamic features of ionic WLA complexes in biphasic media; and 4) synthesized the first series of crystalline WLA coordination polymers, observing the dynamic structural changes of the imbedded-WLA subunits. 

Intellectual merit

We made important fundamental contributions to the fields of chemistry, materials science, and nanotechnology that have implications in a variety of fields. For example, we developed a new coordination chemistry-based fluorescent molecular switch for potential use as a sensor; a novel type of redox-activated complex to harness the catalytic activity of the metal center in a switchable manner; and strategies to incorporate stimuli-responsive WLA subunits into infinite coordination polymer (ICP) particles resulting in dynamic control over particle morphology. Furthermore, the synthesis of the trans-WLA complexes represents a new strategy that is allowing us to expand the scope of architectures that can be targeted (e.g., 3D crystalline metal organic frameworks (MOFs)), enabling access to switchable inorganic solids. Also, our work looking at taking advantage of biphasic media to regulate supramolecular structure in the context of the WLA opens a door to performing chemistry in new environments, where we can utilize the stimuli-responsive properties of WLA complexes to multiple ends. Taken together, these insights increase our understanding of supramolecular, inorganic, and organometallic chemistry in general and show how the WLA can be used to realize novel dynamic structures, providing a new structural motif to control the dynamics of more and more complex structures and materials using coordination chemistry at metal nodes. 

Broader impacts

This award has permitted young scientists (e.g., graduate students) to receive training in the fields of coordination and organometallic chemistry and organic synthesis and to gain experience in performing chemical and analytical techniques, such as NMR, FT-IR, and mass spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction. Furthermore, the synthetic skills gained by these students have enabled them to participate in interdisciplinary collaborations with their peers in the related areas of materials chemistry, nanoscience and technology, and DNA nanotechnology. For example, by leveraging knowledge of organometallic chemistry gained, novel metal-porphyrin polymers were synthesized that permitted nanoclusters to be prepared via scanning probe block copolymer lithography. Furthermore, results gathered in the context of this grant have served as a basis for young chemists to gain experience in discussing their results and developing oral presentations and written documents to communicate hypotheses, data, and conclusions to their peers and their professional community. Women, URM scientists, and undergraduates have been actively recruited to participate in this project, and they have significantly contributed to aspects of it. In addition, advanced concepts in chemistry and nanotechnology have been disseminated by grant participants to students at local schools and to the general public in a variety of venues. These activities have heightened awareness and engagement with STEM at all levels.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Chad A Mirkin
